title: areas could get lower lockdown tier christmas
story: Ministers are meeting on Wednesday to review England's Tier system and decide whether any parts of the country will face tighter or looser restrictions in the run up to Christmas.The decision comes as both Covid-19 cases and hospital admissions are on the rise across many parts of England, threatening to reverse the declines seen in the wake of the recent national lockdown. London and parts of the South East were moved to Tier 3 on Wednesday. There are, however, glimmers of hope: some areas have seen positive progress on the key Covid metrics since the last allocation of Tiers across England. Here are some of the main areas ministers deciding Tiers are likely to be grappling with:Hopes are high in the Greater Manchester area for a loosening of Tier 3 restrictions, after the region spent much of the summer and autumn under tough local lockdowns.Mayor Andy Burnham, on Wednesday morning, argued there was a “clear case” for moving the area into Tier 2, pointing to the region’s weekly case rate now being below the average across all local authority areas in England.However, the Government is casting a wider net when deciding Tiers, and a handful of badly performing areas may hold the wider region back.Although Greater Manchester’s case rate of 155 per 100,000, in the week to Dec 10, is below the 180 average for England, it’s still above the average case rate of areas that went into Tier 2 on Dec 3.Instead, it’s closer to the Tier 3 average, which came in at 175 per 100,000 - and indeed cases in four out of the ten local authority areas - the city of Manchester, Wigan, Bury and Rochdale - stand above this rate.Likewise, though cases have been in decline in the Greater Manchester area as a whole, the rates in a handful of areas are at best remaining stubbornly high and at worse beginning to creep up again. The city of Manchester has seen weekly cases tick up slightly to 179 per 100,000 from 175 on Dec 2, while Trafford has seen cases move from 96 to 106. Cases are also rising in the key, 60 and over, age group which further muddies the waters. Half of Greater Manchester’s local authority areas have seen a rise in infections among the elderly.This may mean ministers opt for a wait-and-see approach with Greater Manchester.Parts of the South West currently in the Tier 3, including North Somerset, the city of Bristol and South Gloucestershire, may have a better chance of moving down a Tier.None of these three local authority areas have a case rate above the Tier 3 average - with rates at 126, 115 and 153 respectively.But, cases are not declining uniformly in this region. South Gloucestershire has seen total cases rise, while infections among over 60s in the city of Bristol are up. North Somerset, on the other hand, has been heading in the right direction on both metrics.When England’s lockdown Tier allocation was announced, just two areas - less than one per cent - were placed in Tier 1, the level with the loosest set of rules.Very low case rates in Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly and the Isle of Wight helped keep these areas free of tough restrictions. Since Dec 3 their key Covid-19 metrics have continued to perform well, making a tougher tier doubtful. Herefordshire, currently in Tier 2, may be in with a shot of Tier 1 - the West Midlands county has seen 46 cases per 100,000 in the week up to Dec 10, down from 61 cases in the week up to Dec 2. The rate in Cornwall is 21 per 100,000 and the Isle of Wight’s, just 14. Cases are not rising in the over 60s in Herefordshire and the area’s so-called positivity ratio - the share of swabs that come back from labs with a positive result - has dropped below the important threshold of 5 per cent, suggesting testing there is keeping up with cases.A less likely contender could be the city of York, which has seen similar progress to Herefordshire and now has a case rate of 62 per 100,000. What may hold York back, however, is its neighbours. Even though cases are declining across Yorkshire and The Humber, the vast majority of neighbouring areas still have a case rate above the Tier 2 average. You can use our postcode tool below to discover how your local area has fared on the Government’s key Covid-19 metrics. Case rates aside, ministers are taking into account how fast infections are spreading and among what age groups, along with new admissions to hospitals and the strength of the local testing system.Enter your postcode below to see if where you live is headed in the right direction.  More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: biden would foolish repeat foreign policy blunders obama era
story: Now that Joe Biden has officially been confirmed as America’s 46th president, he can begin work in earnest on one of his fundamental policy goals: rebuilding relations with Washington’s key allies, many of whom have been left feeling bruised and battered by their encounters with the Trump administration. This is particularly true in Europe, where Mr Trump’s combative approach on issues such as the disinclination of many European leaders to pay their fair share towards defending the Western alliance, as well as their protective trade instincts, has been the cause of transatlantic friction.Mr Biden’s impending arrival in the Oval Office will therefore be greeted with enormous relief in many European capitals in the expectation that his presidency will herald a return to the cosy consensus that underpinned their dealings with the White House during Barack Obama’s eight years in office.On issues ranging from China to Iran, Russia to North Korea, political leaders around the world will be hoping that Mr Biden will be able to restore America’s global role while at the same time forging a more constructive dialogue with its allies.Mr Biden has already intimated that he intends this to be his direction of travel, declaring that he wants to “renew the spirit and shared purpose of the free world” by creating a US-led coalition of liberal democracies to challenge the rise of authoritarian regimes. The prospect of Washington adopting a more inclusive approach to tackling global challenges is reflected in the incoming administration’s initial appointments.Antony Blinken, the new Secretary of State who previously worked for the Obama administration, describes himself as a multilateralist who is committed to the transatlantic relationship and “believes the world is safer for the American people when we have friends, partners and allies.” Jake Sullivan, the National Security Advisor, is another veteran of the Obama White House who, having worked on securing the Iran nuclear deal, now wants to revive it. Then there is General Lloyd Austin, the nominee for defence secretary, who was responsible for implementing the Obama administration’s military withdrawal from Iraq.The appointment of so many Obama-era political retreads in the new administration certainly lends credence to the view that Mr Biden intends to adopt a similar approach to his Democratic predecessor. The only problem is that the world has changed a great deal in the four years since Mr Obama left office. The woeful naivety that defined the former president’s approach to tackling Washington’s foes is simply no longer tenable.Take China. Even though Mr Obama acknowledged that Beijing posed the greatest challenge to American supremacy, and pivoted American policy towards the Pacific, he kow-towed to China’s communist rulers in the erroneous belief that this might somehow encourage the regime to mend its ways.Instead, four years on, Beijing stands accused of inflicting untold damage on the global economy by trying to cover up its role in the original coronavirus outbreak, persecuting the minority Uighur population and crushing the last vestiges of democratic government in Hong Kong.Russia, so long as President Vladimir Putin remains in power, is another lost cause so far as the incoming Biden administration is concerned. Mr Obama’s attempts to improve ties with Moscow, which resulted in the toe-curling embarrassment of former US Secretary of State Hillary Clinton presenting Sergei Lavrov, her Russian opposite number, with a plastic “reset” button in 2009, ended with Moscow’s illegal annexation of Crimea and the Russian military committing unspeakable war crimes in Syria.Then there is the Iran deal, which Mr Obama still regards as the crowning foreign policy achievement of his presidency. Having wasted the tens of billions of dollars Tehran received for signing the deal on expanding Iran’s unwelcome influence throughout the Middle East, the regime is now intensifying its efforts to produce weapons-grade nuclear material. Moreover, under the terms of the deal the Obama administration signed off, Iran will be perfectly within its rights to build atom bombs within five years.Mr Obama, to judge by the preening self-regard that emerges from the pages of his latest memoir, The Promised Land (currently being serialised - where else? - on the BBC), would be the last person to concede the shortcomings of his approach.The lamentable failings of his administration, though, were clearly understood by Mr Trump, whose tenure in the Oval Office saw a dramatic shift in Washington’s outlook, one where extreme pressure was applied against America’s foes, instead of naive expressions of goodwill.Mr Biden would be well-advised to heed the lessons of the Trump legacy rather than seeking to overturn them. At a time when the challenge posed by authoritarian regimes, whether in Beijing, Moscow or Tehran, is clearly in the ascendant, we now live in a world that simply cannot afford another four years of Obama-style naivety.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: ferry passengers kept ship overnight crew test positive coronavirus
story: More than 300 ferry passengers have been kept on a ship overnight after six members of the crew tested positive for coronavirus.The Stena Line ship, due to travel from Merseyside to Belfast, was held in dock at Birkenhead overnight on Tuesday. title: gay conversion therapy ban called almost 400 religious leaders
story: Gay conversion therapy should be banned, according to a “landmark” pledge from almost 400 relgious leaders from around the world.The UK Government has brought together senior faith leaders to sign “an historic declaration” calling for an end to violence and criminalisation of LGBT+ people, as well as a global ban on conversion therapy.The Foreign, Commonwealth and Development Office (FCDO) has funded a conference that is being held on Wednesday online to mark the launch of the Global Interfaith Commission on LGBT+ Lives, bringing together hundreds of religious leaders from around the world. The Declaration has been signed by leaders from 35 countries and all main religions, including Archbishop Desmond Tutu with eight other archbishops, Rabbi David Rosen and the former President of Ireland, Dr Mary McAleese.The conference comes after it was announced in the summer that plans to ban controversial gay conversion therapy will be brought forward following the government’s completion of a study on the issue.Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the practice was absolutely abhorrent and has no place in this country.The term conversion therapy refers to any form of treatment or psychotherapy which aims to change a person's sexual orientation or to suppress a person's gender identity.Ahead of the conference, Crispin Blunt MP, Chair of the APPG on Global LGBT+ Rights, said:  “The religious element around sustaining the criminalisation of LGBT people around the world - many of whose countries have not addressed the laws they inherited from British administration - is very significant. “All avenues ought to be engaged to enable people to be able to lead the life they want to lead. Changing what is perceived as a default position of the major religions is critical in unpicking the support for this intolerable dicrimination.”The Rt Revd Paul Bayes, Bishop of Liverpool, who co-chairs the Commission alongside Rabbi Laura Janner-Klausner, Senior Rabbi to Reform Judaism, will say at the event: “Today is a landmark day in global faith and LGBT+ relations. “For too long, religious teachings have been misused – and are still being misused – to cause deep pain and offence to those who are lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender, queer and intersex. “This must change, which is why we have joined forces to launch the Global Interfaith Commission on LGBT+ Lives which aims to provide a strong and authoritative voice amongst those who wish to affirm the sanctity of life and the dignity of all.”The Declaration recognises the harm that certain religious teaching has caused the LGBT+ community and asks for their forgiveness, before calling on all nations to end violence against LGBT+ people as well as a global ban on conversion therapy. It ends with a call for all to “celebrate inclusivity and the extraordinary gift of our ersity”The conference will hear from over 20 speakers from across the faiths and is being live streamed.It also features messages from the Bishop of London, Rt Revd Sarah Mullally, the Argentinian Ambassador to Italy, HE Roberto Manuel Carles and the UN Independent Expert for Sexual Orientation &amp Gender Identity, Victor Madrigal-Borloz.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: government masterminding sell out brussels brexiteers
story: 'Act in haste and repent at leisure goes the old adage. When it comes to a thousand-page international treaty on your country’s ability to self-govern, one would argue that remorse lasts in perpetuity.With news today that MPs may work until Christmas Eve to pass a deal with the EU, or, worse still, may not vote until next year and retrospectively correct domestic law to recognise an agreement, we can safely say due scrutiny of whatever Boris brings back is for the birds. That is extremely ominous indeed. Cast your minds back to the Withdrawal Agreement – the dreaded rehash of Theresa May’s subjugation that Johnson himself called vassalage – and you may remember that it was first revealed on October 17 2019, a luxurious three months before it actually became statute. An entire election campaign to get Johnson, and the Brexiteer family favourites, back in office was built around how fantastic this deal supposedly was. The Withdrawal Agreement Act was passed before Christmas by an ebullient Boris and put into statute on January 23, with freshly elected Brexiteers hardly able to recant their campaign compliance.The same legislation (in particular the appended Political Declaration) outlines the very framework of the future deal we await today. Brexiteer MPs claiming not to know what horrors lie in store are thus rather absurd.Wind the clock forward half a year and one time ERG Chair Steve Baker confessed in The Critic that he had no idea there would be a border down the Irish Sea. It’s one thing to miss small print, but accidentally annexing a constituent country to a foreign power is a monumental mistake. This precipitated the utter farce of having to draw up the Internal Markets Bill and breaking the international law enshrined in the Withdrawal Agreement to protect UK food supply chains – legislation only apparently needed in the event of No Deal and now alarmingly dropped.In giving up the contentious elements of the IMB designed to mitigate the worst scenarios emanating from the highly controversial Northern Irish Protocol, Michael Gove has essentially conceded that Belfast will be left in the Customs Union, despite repeated assurances that the UK would depart from the EU intact.To agitate now over the devilish detail of a coming deal is rather too little, too late. The damage was done last year, with the Withdrawal Agreement – readily extolled as hustings took place up and down the country – granting the Conservative Party major leverage over backbenchers and prospective parliamentarians. Hitherto pivotal voices joined in chorus to approve the oven-ready deal, such as that of Brexit-backing QC Martin Howe, who happened to vie to be the Conservative candidate, albeit unsuccessfully, in the seat of Beaconsfield vacated by Dominic Grieve.Howe today has rightly decried not having access to the draft legal texts, enabling any forthcoming treaty to be dumped as a fait accompli. But Howe should know what the deal will look like, having counselled Brexiteers into backing the Withdrawal Agreement and the Political Declaration during the election. All the unconscionable concessions are those being wrestled over today: paragraph 77 of the Political Declaration outlines a level playing field, paragraph 73 fixed fishing quotas and paragraph 131 the EU’s own Courts of Justice as arbiter of future disputes. For anyone to have asserted that a simple free trade agreement could somehow emerge from such a text was bizarre.We are now facing a situation where, as deadlines loom, the Commons may be forced to amend retrospectively domestic law to accommodate a dreadful deal, a move that Leader of the House and famed Brexiteer Jacob Rees-Mogg admits would be hugely controversial and legally contentious, yet is seemingly happy to enable.Boris has checkmated the UK by legally enshrining mass concessions via the Withdrawal Agreement and failing to prepare thoroughly for a No Deal outcome. Yet he was aided and abetted by the very politicians now fearing a great sell-out to Brussels, who were complicit in cheerleading the oven-ready deal that spells out much of what is to come.The writing may not be in statute yet. But it is clearly on the wall.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: queen marys dolls house dining set expected fetch 30000 auction
story: A miniature dining set designed for Queen Mary's dolls' house is expected to fetch up to £30,000 at auction.The 70-piece set, including serving dishes, tureens, bowls, dinner plates, side plates and platters, was made by tableware store Thomas Goode &amp Co, which still has royal warrants with the Queen and the Prince of Wales.The dinner set, which is one twelfth of the normal size, is an exact replica of the set presented to the Queen in 1924.Thomas Goode &amp Co made one copy of every commissioned piece for their own archives, where it has remained ever since.The London-based company was asked to create two miniature China dinner services, one for the dolls' scullery and the other for the main dining room.Johnny Sandelson, executive chairman, said the sets took two years to make.“Every piece had to be an exact, fully functioning replica, so the teapots flow and the dishes could be used,” he said.The doll’s house was commissioned by the nation to thank Queen Mary for her efforts during the war and was deemed a way of showcasing British craftsmanship.The house, one of the most popular tourist attractions at Windsor Castle, includes a library with versions of real books, a wine cellar containing real wines and a gramophone playing the national anthem.The replica dinner service will be sold with a copy of a handwritten letter from Queen Mary thanking “all the very kind people who have helped to make the dolls' house the most perfect present that anyone could receive”.Online bidding dates takes place between December 22 and January 8 at Sotheby's.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: 10000 worth christmas presents being
story: AdvertorialWhy £, worth of Christmas presents are being given to people who buy milkGraham’s The Family Dairy is surprising customers with hampers of fresh dairy products and vouchers to dine at top restaurantsmirrorShareCommentsByDave MastersHelena Pozniack:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC AdvertorialDr Robert Graham, chairman of Graham’s The Family DairyCows still need milking, even in the middle of a pandemic. And owners of Graham’s The Family Dairy in Scotland have continued to rise at am throughout this year to tend their  strong herd of Jersey cows and ensure customers as far away as the Highlands can get milk delivered to their doors.   But while dairy purchases have soared, Graham’s has seen the fortunes of local hospitality businesses plummet - and the family wanted to help out with a Christmas Advent of giving. Thataposs why every day in December in the run up to Christmas, Graham’s is giving away gts to customers - in the form of hampers of fresh dairy products and vouchers to dine out at some of Scotland’s best local restaurants - to the value of £, in all.  As part of our campaign with KFC, we are sharing stories of everyday people doing extraordinary things to help their community - those heroes who want to give people more of what they love. And today we salute Graham’s The Family Dairy for doing just that. “As a family of farmers, it’s not an option to stop milking our cows - le goes on. We soon realised people needed more help than ever,” says Dr Robert Graham, chairman of the dairy in Stirlingshire, who’s worked on the farm in the village of Bridge of Allan all his le, and still oversees the early morning milking. “Our teams have worked incredibly hard over the past few months, and with Christmas coming up, our business wanted to give something back to communities. “Eating good Scottish food with friends and family is such a pleasure,” says Dr Graham, who hopes the scheme will spread a little Christmas joy now and into the new year. “The past few months have been incredibly tough for restaurants and cafes as most of them are small family-run operations.”  When lockdown began earlier this year, Graham’s, which works with more than  farmers across Scotland, mobilised teams to deliver milk, butter and other fresh products direct to more people’s houses as customers stocked up on home baking staples such as butter, eggs and cream. Founded by Dr Graham’s father in , the business has grown from pony-and-cart doorstep deliveries to supplying shops, hotels and restaurants around the UK. Dr Graham works with his son , who’s now managing director and daughter Carol who leads marketing. It was Dr Graham who back in the s decided to buy some  Jersey cows from the Queen’s herd in Windsor - these produce the rich creamy milk for which the dairy is renowned. Keen to help out local cafes, the dairy has also decided to appoint a new milk ambassador in recognition of a café owner or barista whose community spirit shines through. Staff were won over by a local coffee lover and entrepreneur Michelle Kibaris, owner of Fallen Tree Coffee, who runs a mobile coffee truck around rural Blair Drummond near Stirling. She thinks the rich gold-top milk produced by Graham’s Jersey herd makes the best coffee and is delighted to receive free milk from the dairy for a year - worth some £. “I have so many ideas for the business,” she says. For many, food is more than just fuel to keep us going, it’s a way of showing our love and bringing comfort in a dficult time. This year may have been tough but it’s good to remember it has also served up some incredible stories of kindness, determination and joy in communities across the UK. And we think that calls for more…gravy! To add some festive cheer, and give us all more of what we love, KFC have created the new Gravy Burger Box Meal, featuring a fillet burger with added gravy!

title: christmas transport chiefs three pieces
story: NewsChristmas transport chiefs three pieces of advice for people travelling home for holidaysSir Peter Hendy has been put in charge of ensuring people can get home for Christmasthey want to visit family in bubbles - but he has vital tips for holiday travelmirrorShareCommentsByMikey SmithPolitical Correspondent:,  DEC NewsTravellers are advised to book tickets early " %, rgba, rgba, url"Join the Secret Elves to discover the best shopping deals and things to do this ChristmasSpread the Christmas cheer!When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Governmentaposs Christmas transport tsar has shared three pieces of vital advice for people heading home for the holidays. Sir Peter Hendy, who has been put in charge of ensuring people can travel home safely over the festive period, told a committee of MPs that Christmas bubbles would still be going ahead as far as he was aware. And he said train firms would be ensuring extra capacity on the network, with most companies holding % of seats back from sale to ensure people can travel safely. It comes as the four nations of the UK hold fresh talks today about the way forward after medical journals warned the five-day Christmas rules relaxation is a “blunder” that will cost “many lives”. Askedthe bubble plans were going ahead, Sir Peter told the Transport committee: It is as far as I know as I speak at just after  oaposclock on Wednesday th December. He added: I know that there was some discussion yesterday but the view Iaposm taking about this is that the four governments advice to their citizens about staying healthy and safe is their advice, and our job in the transport sector is to make travel available for those who wish to use it. And I think the advice currently still enables people to travel and the transport industry should therefore prepare as much as we can to allow them to do so. title: what australian style brexit deal
story: NewsWhat is an Australian-style Brexit deal - and why its spin by Boris JohnsonBoris Johnson keeps saying Australian terms instead of no-deal Brexit when in reality they meant the same thing. Heres why the PM is saying it - and whats wrong with his catchphrasemirrorShareCommentsByGeorgia Mulraine:,  DEC NewsBoris Johnson keeps saying Australian terms instead of no-deal Brexit " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAs Brexit negotiations drag on past the initial deadline, the prospect of a no-deal on  December is looming large. Boris Johnson has repeatedly said the UK should go for the ‘Australia option.’Yet an aposAustralia-style dealapos isn’t preferable to no deal - they are essentially the same thing. Under this arrangement, EU trading rules would cease to exist in the UK on January  at the end of our transition period. That will slap tarfs overnight on much of the £bn a year in trade which the UK enjoys with the EU. And it’s because of that huge amount of trade that it’s far too simplistic to just call no-deal the Australia option. We’re on the EU’s doorstep - not the other side of the world. So here is the Prime Minister’s potential ‘no-deal alternative’ explained - and some of the problems with it. What is an Australian-style Brexit deal   By seeking to negotiate a trade arrangement with the EU “Australian style”, Britain will adopt Australian terms. This means no trade deal with the EU. And it means Britain would mainly deal with the EU under the standard World Trade Organisationrules. Traded goods are subject to a range of customs checks, quota restrictions and tarfs. These include import tarfs from the EU on % of all food consumed in the UK. There would be % tarfs on imported trousers and blouses and % tarfs on car imports to the UK, adding £, to the average cost of a car from the EU. All this is another way of saying the UK would have no favourable access to the EU market. UK businesses would face the EU’s standard WTO tarfs when trying to export to the continent, and EU businesses would face the UK’s standard WTO tarfs when trying to export to the UK. Australia is not the only nation which trades with the EU this way. So why ‘Australia-style deal’  There are other nations which have more favourable trading terms with the EU. However, Australia is known for being a developed and prosperous country which has historic links with the UK. This is not the first time the government has looked to Australia for inspiration. The Conservatives have also used the phrase ‘Australian-style points-based’ to describe their new post-Brexit immigration system, despite grave human rights concerns about Australia’s immigration system. Why doesn’t the Prime Minister just call it a no-deal  By constantly referring to the outcome as ‘Australian-style’ arrangements, the Prime Minister is making a no-deal Brexit sound more palatable.It is a spin on the outcome of a no-deal because of the fears over the damaging consequences. The Office for Budget Responsibility predicts that a no-deal Brexit would knock around two percentage points off GDP growth in .And the governor of the Bank of England has said that the long-term effect on the UK economy would be worse than the coronavirus pandemic.What’s wrong with calling it an Australia-style deal, then   The EU is the UKaposs biggest single trading partner. This is partly because of the simple reason that the UK is a neighbouring country to the EU. Australia is on the other side of the world. Some £bn of our trade in  - almost half - was with the EU. By comparison, only one of the top  countries for Australian exports in  was in the EU - and that was the UK. It accounted for .bn in , according to research for the Parliament of Australia. The UK relies on the EU for the operation of just-in-time supply chains in sectors such as cars, pharmaceuticals and food. The border checks and delays which would happen much more with an “Australia deal” have far less impact on EU-Australia trade than they would on EU-UK trade. We don’t just have ferry and flight links with the EU that don’t exist for Australia - we also have the Channel Tunnel. Then there’s the question of the shock to our economy of a no-deal exit. Unlike Australia, we’ve gotten used to decades of tarf-free trade with our nearest neighbours. That means our economy - not to mention the customs systems at ports and so on - will have to adjust to a “new normal”we don’t get a deal. For Australia, things can only get better from here.

Ilie Para and Marta Para-Bloj, both , took pictures of the Audemars Piguet Royal Offshore Oak  carat rose gold watch at the luxury store five days before the theft. They then ed with their son to carry out the theft on September  this year. They managed to steal the pricey  carat rose gold watch by swapping it with a replica hidden in the boyaposs hood when the sales assistant turned her back to them, Southwark Crown Court heard. The Romanian couple were stopped by police days later at the port of Dover as they were attempting to go home. Para and Para-Bloj both admitted theft from a shop with Para being jailed for  months while his we Para-Bloj sentenced to eight months in jail. Judge Michael Grieve, QC, told the pair they had ‘groomed’ their young child to help them commit the theft. He said: ‘You took part in what has aptly been described as a sophisticated, well-planned and audacious plan to steal an expensive watch using your six-year-old child as a key part in its execution. Prosecutor Dominic Hockley said the couple were at Harrods five days before the theft, trying on ious timepieces. He said: When they found the watch they were interested in they took photographs, no doubt intending to obtain a realistic replica. When the pair ed the second time, they pretended to be buying a present for the woman’s father. The prosecutor said: When the sales assistant took the other watches and placed them back in the stacks, as she did that, Mr Para took off the genuine watch he had been trying on and swapped it with a fake that was concealed in his child’s coat hood. He immediately placed the fake watch on the display tray. The thieves then claimed they needed some time to ‘think about it’ before leaving the store. The sales assistant was not aware of the swap until the next day when a colleague noticed the watch’s dial was dferent and it was missing its serial number.  Police were alerted and the couple were stopped at the port of Dover with Para wearing the watch on his left wrist. Ioana Nedelcu, defending, told the court Para-Bloj was pregnant at the time of her arrest and had ‘suffered tremendously’ after miscarrying while in prison.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA drive-thru vaccine hub has opened with priority patients getting the jab while still behind the wheel. Cars pulled up to the vaccination centre at Hyde Leisure Centre, Greater Manchester, with medics administering the jab within minutes. The borough’s clinical commissioning grouphas worked with GPs and Tameside council to establish the first primary care network vaccine hub, with four more to come in the following weeks. The first batch of the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine arrived in the borough on Tuesday, with vaccinations starting at Hyde Leisure Centre today. Bosses say that the first to be invited for vaccinations will be over-s who are registered with a Hyde GP practice, with further invitations going out ‘as soon as possible’ as the programme ‘rapidly evolves’.The Hyde site is a drive-through model but chiefs are advising that, where possible, people who need the vaccine are not the ones driving, reports the Manchester Evening News.However,a resident does not have someone to drive them to the hub they will be able to park up and walk through to receive the vaccine and then wait in their car for  minutes afterwards. Residents will receive an invitation to come forward for the vaccine at the right time – which will most likely come in the form of a letter, either from their GP or the national NHS. It will include all the information needed to book an appointment, including the person’s NHS number. People are being urged not to contact the NHS or their GP to get an appointment until they receive this letter. All those vaccinated will also be booked in for a booster jab  days later.In a joint statement, the co-chairs of the Tameside and Glossop CCG, Dr Asad Ali and Dr Ashwin Ramachandra said: “Our staff have been working around the clock to prepare for the launch of the biggest immunisation programme in our country’s history. “Through partnership working we have quickly established the first vaccine hub in Tameside ready to carry out le-saving vaccinations for the most vulnerable, while more hubs are being prepared to roll out vaccinations across Tameside and Glossop.” Following extensive trials, the Pfizer BioNTech vaccine is the first safe and effective vaccine for Covid- to be approved by regulators. hiefs say that GP-led primary care networks will now begin vaccinating next week with more practices joining in on a phased basis over the coming months.  Larger vaccination centres will begin operating when further supplies of the vaccine are made available. Hubs will be set up in networks for Ashton, Glossop – which will cover Gamesley, Denton – covering Droylsden and Audenshaw, and Stalybridge – covering Dukinfield and Mossley. Those receiving the vaccine may not be protected until at least seven days after their second dose. People who are suffering from a fever-type illness or symptoms of Covid- should postpone having the vaccine until they have recovered.

title: europe talks brits europeans bond
story: NewsBrits and Europeans bond and share stories over Zoom ahead of Brexit crunch dayBrits and European Union residents spoke about le, coronavirus, and politics as the December  deadline looms in our Europe Talks series collaborating with newsrooms across the ChannelmirrorShareCommentsByMaryam QaiserClaire Donnelly:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsBob Officer, , a retired electrical engineer from Bucks, spoke to an Austrian farmer for the Europe Talks series" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailBrexit is finally down to the wire, as we face an uncertain future outside the European Union. It is a seismic moment in our country’s history – but also one where our ties to our European neighbours have rarely been so important. That’s why the Mirror is proud to have taken part this week in Europe Talks – in partnership with  other newspapers and websites across Europe led by Zeit Online in Germany.Our project matched thousands across Europe for a video call chat about le, lockdown, Brexit and the coronavirus.Twenty-thousand people signed up across Europe, including , from the UK. Our matching algorithm was able to pair , of these people between countries from Britain to Bulgaria. The furthest match was a postman from the Azores and a young Greek woman. The greatest dferences between the answers given were between Bulgaria and Switzerland, while the smallest were between Belgium and Portugal. Find out below what happened when a Scottish actor met a Greek engineer, two teachers from Wales and Germany chatted, and others met matches from Romania, France, Austria, Lithuania and Italy. England  Lithuania Brian Langan, , former prison worker, from near Bury, Lancashire. Vincas Grigas, , academic from Vilnius, Lithuania. Brian has recently recovered from Covid and was keen to know how Vincas, whose we is a GP, felt during the pandemic. Was he afraid  “Yes,” says Vincas, , “because my we is a family doctor, so she is with people all time. There is danger.” But, he adds brightly: “You have the vaccine now  Will you take it ” Brian says he will. Then, much to Vincas’ delight, Brian explains he’s just bought a motorbike and rescued lots of battery hens, as well as a very loud rooster.  Vincas’ we, Jurate, , and his daughter, Satrija, four, are keen to get chickens on the land surrounding their home, just outside Vilnius, and there is talk of sheep. Brian and Vincas are both sorry to see Britain leaving the EU. “It was better that we had a shared view,” Brian says. “I think it will be sad when we do come away.” “Yes,” agrees Vincas. “It seems very sad.”  England  Austria Maria Loidl, , farmer from Kaindorf, Austria. Bob Officer, , retired electrical engineer from Hazlemere, Bucks. Since retiring, Bob spends three months of the year travelling with his we as well as renovating classic cars. Maria owns an organic fruit farm, but dreams of travelling. After their chat she even jokes she might visit Bob. Bob says: “We are very much a ided country, as you’re probably aware.” Maria adds: “I am a little sad about Brexit because we will miss Britain in the community, and I think everything will get more dficult.” Bob says: “Youaposre much stronger when you are part of a big group.”  Both have daughters due to get married next year. Maria says her children will be visiting at dferent times over Christmas because their father has a heart condition. The pair promise to visit each other. Maria says: “I think it is necessary to meet new people. A lot of problems come because people don’t speak enough to each other.” Bob nods: “I totally agree.”  England  Romania Laura Bevan, , a mum-of-two and civil servant from Widnes, Cheshire. Gabriela Damian, , environmental consultant, from Timișoara, Romania. When Laura asks Gabriela what she thinks about Brexit, Gabriela says that a “country should do what suits them.” She says: “I’m not a big fan of the European Union, it is very hard to match people in one family, so it is so much harder to match countries, we have dferent cultures, dferent interests, dferent backgrounds.  She adds: “I love England, but I think it has lost its own personality.” The pair also disagreed over mask-wearing. “I am very annoyed with wearing masks,” Gabriela says. “I don’t see the benefit, we can’t breathe properly and it is scary. It is like a science fiction movie. It is a limitation of our right to breathe fresh air freedom.” Laura is happy to wear a mask. She says: “I have lost people I know to Covid.” Gabriela says she won’t be getting vaccinated. “I won’t be something in my body that doesn’t belong there. The human body is intelligent and perfect.”  Ireland Greece   Jean Kelly, , musician, from south east London. Maria Pikni, , garment worker, from Athens. Maria says Greece still hasn’t recovered from the financial crash – she was earning €, euros a month before , compared to just € now.She says Covid has made things even worse.Jean, , is a musician originally from Ireland.Her concerts have been cancelled but she is still teaching piano and harp classes over Zoom. Maria works for a clothing company. “I have a paper which says I am allowed to be outside my home from am to take the train and metro and I have to be back by pm,” she says. “The second lockdown is much harder than the first. It is like weaposre prisoners in our own house.” She will be alone on Christmas day because of the risk of infecting her elderly mother. “I am getting very really concerned about Brexit,” Jean says, “I feel like we’ve been hit very hard by the pandemic and now Brexit. I didn’t vote for it and I was very sorry when it went through. It now feels strange to be Irish in England for the first time. I felt like home before, but now I feel like a foreigner here.”  England  FranceSusan Hunt, , Manchester Airport worker from Runcorn, Cheshire. Carolina Rengo, , English teacher  hockey trainer in Madrid, originally from France. “This is my third time furloughed,” Susan says. “I can’t wait to go back, I’m going stir crazy at home.”  Carolina, is French but lives in Spain. “I have been praying for time to stop for years,” she says. “Every minute of the day, I would be playing hockey, doing three jobs and studying two degrees and still have a social le and travel the world.” Carolina has spent the summer travelling around Spain while Susan has been forced to cancel four holidays due to the pandemic. Carolina says Brexit is “heartbreaking”. “I lived in London for a year, I have friends who were for and against Brexit. We have reached  years without a war in Europe. I don’t want to think about Europe breaking up, for me living in Spain, the only safety I feel is coming from the EU.”  Scotland  Greece Bruce Henderson, , actor, from Dunfermline, Scotland. Manos Sfakakis, , electrical engineer, from Nea Smyrni, Greece. Manos proudly shows Bruce his one-year-old daughter Myrto. “I work in the most unethical sector that one can work in, in the oil and gas industry, so I will have a lot of guilt to pass onto my daughter when she grows up.” Bruce, studying D animation at college, is more optimistic. He says: “In China there are huge cities, where they have replaced their entire bus fleets with electrical buses, it is on a scale that is amazing.” Manos says people in Greece can feel powerless. “We are like a little village. Greece has a tremendously small impact on whatever happens.”  Bruce explains his philosophy of le: “I took the view a few years ago, you have one le, so go and do the things that make you happy.” The pair set up a second Zoom to carry on chatting. Wales  Germany Alison Ward, , teacher from Bridgend, Wales. Martina Doerr, , teacher from Osterode am Harz, Germany. Alison, a mum-of-seven, was a primary school teacher but is now a full-time carer for her husband.  Martina teaches English and French. She says: “Alison I always think caring for relatives is something that is taken for granted. I must say I find you very courageous, I admire you.” Alison home-schooled her younger children during lockdown. Martina says she thinks schools in Germany should have remained open during the pandemic. “I could see some children were falling behind academically and some children didn’t have the necessary equipment,” she says. “There were also parents who were working in jobs where they just couldn’t look after their children.  “But I agree with you Alison, it shouldn’t come at any cost,the cases are really bad, they should close.” The pair say they will be keeping in touch with each other and hope to arrange another call. England  Italy Amy O’Connell, , a British mum of two from Bucks. Ruggero Delladio, , export manager, Verona, Italy.  Amy and Ruggero agree both of their governments could have handled the Covid crisis better. “It was very, very bad,” says Ruggero, who lives near Verona with his we and two grown-up children. “We suffered for a long time.” “Yes,” agrees Amy. “We didn’t act quick enough. We were seeing what was happening to you, in Italy but we were still too slow. We’ve had a lot of loss, but it’s had positives, it’s made us closer as a family to be honest.”

Peyton, who weighed just lbs oz when she was born, had to be transferred from a cot back into an incubator when a Covid test came back positive. First-time mum, Tracy, , said Peyton cried tears for the first time while being given a swab test, and said it was one of the hardest things she had ever had to see. Dad-of-two AJ, , was not allowed to visit his daughter due to the restrictions but the family are looking forward to spending Christmas together in Birkenhead, North Lanarkshire. Tracy said: Itt was kind of unknown for kids to have the virus and whether it would progress and get worse or be alright. She didnapost have any symptoms, just a bit of snfling and a few coughs. Itaposs the same as the adult test - they stuck a swab right up her nose and to the back of her throat. Itaposs the first time Iaposve seen her cry tears. It was so hard and one of the worst things Iaposve seen. Just five days after testing positive for the virus, Peyton was allowed to go home from Wishaw General Hospital, North Lanarkshire - in time for AJaposs th birthday on April  - when she began feeding on her own from a bottle. But despite ing home, Tracy and AJ were terried their baby girl would suffer long-term damage as a result of the illness. Tracy added It was the scariest thing in my le - Peyton had tested positive for a deadly virus. I had to get steroid injections to get her lungs up to scratch, she wasnapost ready to be born. I was worriedher lungs wouldaposve been prepared to deal with the virus. It took five to six months to get rid of that fear, but weaposre watching her grow now. We had only got to see her for an hour a day. The hospital tried to limit the amount of access at one time to parents. The nurses who came to see her were in full PPE. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAt first it was clear, restrictions would be eased for five days at Christmas to let families meet.But now, with coronavirus rampant, families are beginning to question their festive plans.Here, Azeem Majeed, professor of primary care and public health at Imperial College London, and Dr Mike Tildesley, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modelling, give their advice on what to do and not to do. Should the five-day Christmas pause be scrapped  Scientists are calling for the easing of restrictions at Christmas to be ditched and there are signs the Government may reduce the number of days, or number of households allowed to meet. Prof Majeed says: “Because Covid- rates are at a very high level in many parts of the UK, it would be sensible to continue with the current restrictions over the Christmas period, rather than pausing them. “If we don’t pause the five-day relaxation of restrictions and people mix indoors in large numbers with people from other households, we will pay the price for this in January through increases in Covid- cases, hospitalisations and deaths.” Dr Tildesley believes changing the rules so close to Christmas could cause more harm than good. He says: “I would be really worried about the Government changing the rules now, as it may cause a massive drop in trust.” Should schools be allowed to close early so kids can self-isolate before seeing at-risk relatives  Prof Majeed says: “Closing schools should be a decision made by headteachers in discussion with their local authorities and local public health teams. I would allow schools to close early in areas where Covid- rates are high and there are clusters of cases in schools.” Dr Tildesley says that while he would “never advocate” closing schools, the measure would protect elderly relatives. He says: “If you have a vulnerable relative you should do what you can to keep them safe. Isolating for a few weeks before will certainly help minimise the risk.” Should households be allowed to mix during Christmas  Dr Tildesley says letting families come together could help mitigate the effects of the pandemic on mental health, but people must stay in their Christmas bubbles. He says: “We need to have some relaxations of the controls to allow families to be together. We need to think about the non-Covid impact, and wellbeing and mental health are two of those. Butthree or four households are allowed to be together, those households need to be exclusive. You can’t go to meet your mates down the pub then go home to see your granny.”  Eventhey can, should people have a big family Christmas  Prof Majeed says: “I would be cautious about large, indoor Christmas events – particularlyyou have elderly relatives or relatives with serious medical problems.” Dr Tildesley says people should “do what they can to be together and prevent loneliness”. But he adds: “People just need to be aware of the risks and take sensible precautions. “Just because the rule might say three households can meet, it doesn’t mean that number have to mix. “You can also minimise the risk by strictly following the rules in the run-up to Christmas to have as little contact with people outside your household as possible. And during the Christmas period, maintain physical distance, ensure that your home is well ventilated and practise good hygiene, such as regular hand washing.” Could the Christmas pause result in more Covid deaths  Dr Tildesley says yes, but we can reduce the risk by taking sensible precautions. He says: “Any increase in mixing is going to cause more cases, and ultimately, an increase in hospitalisations and deaths. “Butwe limit as much as possible the amount of interactions we have with others in the run-up to Christmas, then hopefully we can keep the risk of that extra mixing as low as possible.”  Won’t going back to a tier system after Christmas make up for it  Dr Tildesley thinks what we do before Christmas is more important. On the other hand,we all mix together and have a normal Christmas then we know that in a normal year most respiratory diseases and hospital admissions increase after Christmas anyway in a non-Covid year, so thereaposs clearly a risk, but it really very much depends on what people do. Itaposs very hard to predict and say aposoh yes, this is going to be a disasterapos or aposnothing is going to happenapos because it really does depend on what people decide to do.A top Tory today urged Brits to make “Easter the new Christmas” after it emerged the Prime Minister is refusing to tighten the rules.Robert Jenrick said people should “come to their own judgements” about whether to meet family next week - despite scientists begging the government to cancel a bubble plan.  The Communities Secretary said his own wider family have changed their plans and will now meet on video calls instead of in person. And he said others may “think on this occasion let’s just keep it small and we can meet up in the Spring - Easter can be the new Christmas for some people”. It comes as the four nations of the UK hold fresh talks today about the way forward after medical journals warned the five-day relaxation is a “blunder” that will cost “many lives”.

Photos emerged of a tiny white house on the island of Elliðaey, a remote island south of Iceland. Being the only building on the deserted island, it has attracted several myths. According to one rumour, the house was built by a billionaire who planned to move to the remote island in the event of a zombie apocalypse. Other people suggested a religious hermit may be living there. Another popular theory - which was later debunked - said that the Icelandic government had gted the island to singer Bjork. Some even claimed the house did not exist but it had been photo-shopped before the pictures were published online. Elliðaey, part of the Vestmannaeyjar archipelago, is now completely deserted but it was inhabited about  years ago. Five families who lived there relied on fishing, hunting puffins and raising cattle.But by the s, the last residents left the island which has been deserted since. The reality surrounding the mysterious house on the island is far less exciting than the theories around it.It was built by the Elliðaey Hunting Association as a base to hunt puffins which feast on the abundant supply of fish in the waters below. The house serves as a hunting base for the group to support their activities on the island. Being on the remote island, the property does not have electricity, running water and indoor plumbing.

The imposing property has suddenly appeared in a billionaire’s village and is protected by huge secrecy, says Russian newspaper Sobesednik. The two main buildings are said to run to , square feet, with , square ft stables. The “classical style” palace in a -acre walled estate during its construction phase was owned by a company called Property-V, and the newspaper suggests that ‘V’ stands for Vladimir, concluding that the sprawling estate must belong to an inidual with the highest Kremlin connections. The sumptuous residence is listed as belonging to the Russian Federation, which the report claims is a “cover” used by “owners of palaces and penthouses associated with the countryaposs leadership”. The report suggests the property is either his or belongs to someone exceptionally close to him. A “housewarming” was held for the Property-V palace last month - but without ostentatious fireworks, said the report.  Another gigantic pad on a clf top on the Black Sea known as the  billion Gelendzhik Palace complete with its own vineyard has been linked to Putin as a bolt hole in the south, despite Kremlin denials. So far there has been no response from Putin’s spokesman to the Sobesednik claims, the latest in a series of “revelations” on his wealth, health and private le in recent weeks, leading to suggestions he is under unprecedented “information attack” from foes. But Putin is due to face the media in a major annual marathon press conference later this week.  The recently completed palace is at Greenfield village which offers “a new standard of country le” with an “impeccable style of elite suburban le and the independence of serene nature”, according to a publicity blurb. It comprises “stately residences, reminiscent of country castles”, and is home to a number of billionaires. The village boasts “beautul parks and bouleds  metreswide….fountains, sculptures, flower beds” and is surrounded by “vast forests”.  Before the palace’s construction was complete the village was said to house the “most expensive house in Russia”, owned by Jordanian billionaire Ziyad Manasir. He was reportedly a guest at the wedding of Putin’s younger adult daughter Katerina Tikhonova, , to the country’s youngest billionaire Kirill Shamalov, , a match that ended in orce. The new palace may be worth some £ million, reports Sobesednik.  Andrey Ertman, representative of the company which was constructing the palace, refused to name the owner “hiding under the pseudonym ‘Russian Federation’”, said the newspaper. This is confidential information. Buyers of such assets do not always strive for publicity. This is their right,” he explained. Companies tied to the new palace and its financing are closely linked to the Russian elite and other stunning properties, it is claimed.

title: christmas hangs in the balance as more talks needed to reach a decision on covid restrictions
story: Nicola Sturgeon has warned that plans to ease Christmas Covid measures may have to be scaled back, as four-nations talks failed to reach a conclusion on how to handle the festivities.The fate of Christmas hung in the balance after discussions between the UK Government and devolved nations stalled without making a formal decision.Talks will resume in a few hours when ministers continue their deliberations amid growing concern that loosening the restrictions will trigger a further resurgence of the virus.Ms Sturgeon discussed Christmas strategies in a call with Cabinet Office Minister Michael Gove and representatives of the Welsh and Northern Irish administrations.Previously, the first minister has announced that between December  and  people in Scotland will be able to form a bubble to celebrate Christmas.Under the current plans, the Christmas bubble can be up to three households, including one extended household, up to a maximum of eight people – not including under-s.The advice states that people can travel anywhere in Scotland and the rest of the UK to form a bubble but local rules should be observed once in situ.There is a case for us looking at whether we tighten the flexibilities that were given, in terms of duration and numbers of people meeting. I will consider the views of the other nations. If we can come to a four-nations agreement, that would be preferable. If that is not possible, the Scottish Government will consider what we think is appropriate.#Nicola SturgeonBut the inter-governmental talks were held as concern grows about a new strain of the Covid virus that was first detected in the south of England but has since been discovered north of the border.At Holyrood, Ms Sturgeon said nine cases of the new strain had been identied in the Greater Glasgow and Clyde health board area, which dated back to November.Ms Sturgeon also announced that Aberdeen City, Aberdeenshire and East Lothian would face tougher restrictions from Friday – moving from level two to level three of the Scottish Government’s tier system.South of the border, the second wave has resulted in millions of people in London and parts of Hertfordshire and Essex moving into England#s toughest tier of coronavirus rules this week.Further concerns about Christmas triggering an acceleration of the virus were raised by two leading medical journals. The Health Service Journal and the British Medical Journal warned people might see the lting of restrictions “as permission to drop their guard”.Speaking ahead of her call with Mr Gove, Ms Sturgeon told MSPs she will not be entering the discussions with a “fixed view”.But the first minister signalled that shortening the period for relaxing restrictions or further limits on the size of bubbles was under consideration. She also said the Scottish Government would not shy away from taking a separate approach to the rest of the UK,it was felt to be necessary.“There is a case for us looking at whether we tighten the flexibilities that were given, in terms of duration and numbers of people meeting,” Ms Sturgeon said. “I will consider the views of the other nations. If we can come to a four-nations agreement, that would be preferable. If that is not possible, the Scottish Government will consider what we think is appropriate. Of course, I will update parliament as soon as there is anything to update parliament on.”Ms Sturgeon has argued that easing restrictions would be a pragmatic response to people’s desire to meet up over the festivities. title: mixed emotions for dundee united full back liam smith after scoring first goal for club
story: Liam Smith admits he was left with mixed emotions after scoring his first goal for Dundee United.The right-back will store his superb strike away in the memory bank but wishes it had counted towards a positive result for the Tangerines.Smith, who troubled Rangers with his runs up the flank, showed terric composure and technique to fire the equaliser in off the far post after James Tavernier had put the Light Blues ahead with a superb freekick on Sunday.However, the runaway league leaders took all three points thanks to Connor Goldson’s header that made it - just before the break.Smith said: “Especially when you don’t score many, you always remember the goals you do score.“That will go into the memory bank.“To be honest, when it came off my foot I didn’t really see exactly where the ball went.“I did eventually see it come back off the post and go the right way into the net.“I was delighted, obviously.“But when you don’t win or get a result, obviously that takes the shine off it.“It is more about wanting to contribute to getting a result more than anything for me and we lost the game.”Smith, justiably, felt United had a good first half, despite going in a goal down at the interval.They then crawled back into a defensive shell as Steven Gerrard’s men went hunting for a third in the second period.Smith said: “We had a game plan that was working and we limited them to very little for a while in the first half.“To lose the game to two set-plays, I think we have to be disappointed.“You set up to stay in the game and to stop them and I think we limited their number of chances.“The first goal was a bit of quality that you can do nothing about.“As for the second one, we will have a look back and see what we could have done better to defend that setplay.“Overall, we were disappointed to lose the game to two setpieces.”Smith was close to the controversial incident that saw Rangers striker Alfredo Morelos receive just a booking for striking home defender Mark Connolly in the face with a combination of elbow and forearm.However, the United man admitted he wasn’t % sure at the time that the Colombian deserved a red instead.“To be honest, it happened that quickly that you react because you think something happened but we’ve not seen it back so I can’t really say how bad it was,” said Smith.“On the pitch, you think something has happened so you claim and shout to the ref but he deemed it a booking.“Hedidn’t really see it because he won the ball and his eye was on the ball the whole time.“He actually said in therethat he didn’t see it coming.“Like I’ve said, I don’t really know how bad it was and whether or not it was worth more than a booking.“The ref gave it as a booking so we just had to get on with it.”With that toughest of fixtures behind them, it doesn#t get much easier for the Tangerines when they travel to Easter Road to face Hibs on Saturday.However, Smith believes they can take something tangible out of the Rangers game even though it was lost.He added: “There were positives for us and I feel, particularly in the first half, that we managed to get up the pitch and create a couple of chances ourselves.“We will now go over it all but there were definitely good things to take from the game on our side.“We now have to take it forward and maybe defend resolutely like that against other teams, title: aberdeen housing scheme in line for expansion with plans for 234 homes submitted
story: A major housing developer has submitted plans for an expansion of their Aberdeen scheme.CALA Homeshave lodged blueprints for the third phase of their Craibstone Estate development.The fresh application from the company is for  homes which include apartments as well as terraced, semi-detached and detached homes.This next part of the development includes affordable properties, as well as the creation of a civic square with the provision of retail units and office space.Ross Maclennan, Land Director at CALA Homes , said: “The first two phases of our Craibstone Estate development have been very well received, with  new residents having already moved into their homes, and we’re pleased to be in a position to progress a planning application for the third phase of this landmark development.“Delivering the third phase will see us surpass the halfway milestone of this flagship community. It is also the first phase to include retail and commercial elements which will be a welcome addition for residents.“We look forward to working with the Council to continue growing this remarkable neighbourhood.”CALA Homes is creating a new community of around  homes at its Craibstone Estate development.The initial plans for the project were submitted in  with  new properties being built as part of the first phase.Another  homes were built at the site and residents moved into their new houses last spring.The decision notice giving the overall scheme approval in principle from the city council three years ago said: “The development of Craibstone South would assist in the delivery of affordable housing and Aberdeen’s share of the housing allocations within the Strategic Development Plan.“Subject to appropriate contributions towards supporting infrastructure it is considered that the benefit to the city in terms of the increased supply of housing would justy approving the application.“The proposal is considered to be on balance in accordance with the Strategic Development Plan and Aberdeen Local Development Plan and would contribute towards the housing land supply.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: co op donates more than 176000 to causes in aberdeen

title: five year old girl donates hundreds of selection boxes to sick children and nurses in aberdeen
story: A selfless five-year-old girl is delivering hundreds of selection boxes and sweet tubs to sick children, and hospital staff and patients in Aberdeen.Lexi Gibson-Hanratty from Aberdeen planned to make the generous donations to Aberdeen Children#s Hospital and Roxburghe House as she was concerned that Santa would be unable to visit them this Christmas in the current restrictions.Goods will also be gted to benefit Lee McAllister#s toy appeal as well.Joined by her mum Megan Gibson and her stepdad Zac Robinson, the pair plan to deliver the treats next weekend. Megan says the idea started after she launched an appeal on Facebook to receive selection box donations, which was an idea of Lexi#s.#Since the coronavirus started and all the restrictions kicked off, Lexi was scared that Santa wouldn’t get into the hospital because he would have to quarantine,# Megan said.#She was really worried that all the sick boys and girls wouldn#t get any presents this year, so she asked mewe could give them some chocolates # as chocolate always makes her smile.#Lexi also wanted to give tubs of sweets to the nurses as they have to work during Christmas with their kids at home. And also to thank them for all they have done during the Covid- crisis.#She was actually in the children#s hospital last year due to a bad accident, so this is another way for us to say thank you.#It all started after I launched a little appeal on Facebook to get our hands on some chocolate and sweets. It started to get shares and follows from thousands of people, so I made a page called Lexi#s Christmas Selection Box Appeal.#Friends and family brought along a number of items to Megan and her daughter. But after Scotia Bar in Aberdeen spread the word of their appeal, the donations flooded in.#Customers from the bar came in with loads of selection boxes # one customer donated £ for us to go and buy sweets,# Megan added.#My cousin works in the Clton Salon and they have over  selection boxes that have been donated from clients. Even Tesco got in touch and donated over  selection boxes, while we also received loads of goods from Lexi#s school # Gilcomstoun School # and her old nursery.#Aberdeen Children#s Hospital, Roxburghe House and Lee McAllister#s toy appeal will all benefit. Megan said: #Lexi chose Roxburghe House as they looked after her grandad before he passed away.#They helped make her and her cousin a memory box, so she wants to give the nurses chocolates. She also wants to treat the family members whose grandparents might be ill to make their Christmas a bit better.#The donations are being made next weekend as the last of the boxes are getting delivered from businesses then.#Lexi wanted to do it on Christmas Eve but because of the -hour quarantine rule, we decided to do it next weekend instead.Scotia Bar customers also bought donations.#I feel so so proud of her and how a five-year-old can think of an idea like this. All the hard work she has done with the sick children, and hospital staff and patients in mind makes me a very proud mum. I#m sure Santa will also be extra proud!#For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: leona lewis joins gary barlow for pj live gig in aberdeen
story: Gary Barlow has announced he will be joined at his PJ Live gig in Aberdeen next year by singing star Leona Lewis.The pair will perform as part of the Take That star’s Music Played By Humans tour, which will be at the Granite City venue on November  next year.mdash Gary BarlowDecember , Welcoming Leona – who carved a glittering career after winning The X Factor in  – Gary said: “I’m so happy to have Leona join the tour next year, she’s such a talented singer. I’ve missed performing so much this year, I’m just really looking forward to getting out there and seeing everyone again.”Leona, whose single Bleeding Love was the best-selling single in the UK in  and topped the US charts, said she was thrilled to be part of Gary’s UK arena tour.She said: “I am overjoyed to be invited to join Gary Barlow next year on what’s set to be an incredible tour! I am huge fan of Gary’s and I can’t wait to share the stage with him and bring back the magic of a live show!“I’ve missed performing so much and am counting down the days until I can be back on the stage singing with my fans who have continued to be amazing throughout this crazy year. See you soon!”Gary had originally planned to tour next June but his gigs were pushed back to autumn because of the coronavirus pandemic. The change in dates meant Beverley Knight, who had been due to join him, couldn’t make it because of previous commitments.The tour is on the back of Gary’s new album, Music Played By Humans, which has rocketed up the charts on its release last month, to score his third Number  solo album.The album features an array of collaborations with stars from around the world including James Corden, Michael Bublé, Sebastián Yatra, Barry Manilow, Chilly Gonzales, Alesha Dixon, Beverley Knight, Ibrahim Maalouf and Avishai Cohen.The album is inspired by Gary’s love of orchestral and big band music which captured his imagination as a child.Tickets for his show are on sale at www.pandjliveFor as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.

title: open premiership gives aberdeen opportunity to grab champions league place dave cormack
story: Chairman Dave Cormack wants Aberdeen to grab the opportunity to qualy for the money-spinning Champions League next season.The teams who finish in the top two of the Premiership this season will qualy for the Champions League.The Premiership winners will enter from the third qualying round and the league runners-up will enter from the second qualying round.Uefa confirmed in the summer the Premiership had secured an extra Champions League position after Scotland secured a spot in the top- coefficients.Aberdeen sit fourth in the table, just three points off second-placed Celtic, although the Hoops hold a game in hand.AskedChampions League qualication was a realistic aspiration this season, Cormack said: “Absolutely, and maybe for the first time in three years the league is kind of open to that opportunity.“Next yearyou get Champions League, even the qualying rounds, you get knocked out of that and you go into the third round of qualying for the Europa League.“And,you go out of that, you have one round to get to the group stages of the Conference.“Every incentive is there for us. We want to do our utmost in the league. We’ve got a good squad and a great bunch of lads andwe keep people fit and healthy we will do okay.“We will go into the transfer windows looking at ins and outs, but January is always a dficult window. We will look at what we can get to push as hard as we can push, as a club.”Aberdeen have qualied for Europe for the last seven seasons under Derek McInnes.However, they have yet to progress beyond the Europa League third qualying round.Breaking into the Uefa top- is a long-term target for Cormack.That th spot is occupied by Moldova’s FC Sherf Tiraspol.Aberdeen currently sit th.Despite the focus on Euro progression, Cormack believes cross-border competition will be a reality within the next decade.He said: “There is no doubt, in particular Celtic, and I don’t blame them, have made it clear that they would like a bigger  to play on. It will take all clubs and in Scottish football, trying to get to a consensus can be a bit of a challenge.“If I look at it selfishly from Aberdeen’s perspective, I do not want to sit back and wait for the crumbs off the table of something we had no input into.“That’s important for us to look at. People talk for example of British leagues.“If Celtic and Rangers went off to the Premier League in some shape or form, where does that leave the rest of us – are we playing Exeter  Plymouth  Where do we go and would our fans want that “It is healthy to have a debate and a discussion over what might be. And we need to do more of that as Premiership clubs, and all clubs in Scotland.”If there was to be an opportunity in the future for Aberdeen to compete in a cross-border competition, Cormack insists the club would enter into a full discussion with supporters.He said: “I got involved in a couple of Zoom calls just recently – in the last couple of months.“It’s a project that Andrew Doyle of SAL Partners in Dublin has been working on with some heavyweight executives around football in Europe. It’s a project that looks like it’s dead now for the reason, that we were told, that Celtic have pulled out.“The message really is that, putting this project aside, we’ll stick our heads in the sandwe don’t think there’s going to be cross-border leagues or European super leagues with isions.“What we have to do, as a country and a group of clubs, is be at the table looking at these opportunities.“Some of them may be appropriate to look at. Some not. But it’s really important that,there’s signicant money on the table that looks like an uplt versus what we have now, it should be looked at by all parties.“Any call on Aberdeen getting involved in something like that would have to be with full consultation with our fans.”For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.
