Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.As Christians, we wait to celebrate again the birth of Christ and to hear once again that often told story of a baby and a manger.We have heard it many times, yet it never loses its charm.However, this Christmas will be dramatically dferent from any Christmas we have ever had. Usually we look forward to the Christmas lights and decorations brightening up the dark winter nights and bringing hope and cheer.This year, we wait and wonder. We wonder what level our area will be in, we wonder what level our family and friends will be in, we wonderwe will be able to see them or have them in our homes or go to their homes.We wonder. We watch the news and hope restrictions will be eased, but we are afraid of that too, as this could lead to the virus spreading. So we wait and watch and wonder – a bit like the shepherds of old, gathered on the hillside, waiting and watching and wondering.It has been a tough few months and for many it has been a gruelling and harrowing few months.How do we celebrate in such times Yet, I have heard so many people say: #Well I’m going to put up my tree and I’m going to do it early to bring some cheer into our lives.#We are a people of hope, even in the darkest days.We wait in the darkness for we know that even the darkest night has the first streaks of dawn to lighten the sky.So as we approach the time of preparing to welcome the Christ child once again, we will wait hopefully.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Scantily-clad in a red and black burlesque-style outfit and sporting a styled pink wig, Tom Donnachy # known on the day as Anna Conda # braved Monday#s chilly weather to walk five kilometres around Campbeltown as part of Kintyre Link Club and ACUMEN#s #take five# challenge.Sarah McFadzean, in her role as a development worker for ACUMEN # Advancing Community Understanding of Mental and Emotional Needs # joined forces with Kintyre Link Club manager Tracy Chambers to launch the challenge at the beginning of November.They were inspired by David Brown, a manager at Campbeltown#s Tescostore, who is completing a personal challenge of running five kilometres every day of  in a bid to raise money for charity as he maintains his fitness.For every kilometre he completes, David donates p of his own money to the charity of his choice for that month. He decided to donate the proceeds from his November fundraising to Kintyre Link Club.The #take five# challenge was created so others could join in by walking, running or doing the exercise of their choice, to raise additional sponsorship for the club.Tom decided to participate in a bid to repay some of the financial and emotional support he has received from Kintyre Link Club.He was joined on Monday by a troupe of supporters, many of whom also took part in the #take five# challenge throughout November.Tom told the Courier: #I suffer with a lot of mental health problems and, without the support of Kintyre Link Club and Tracy, who has been absolutely fantastic, I would have fallen into a really dark place.#Tom#s mental health deteriorated after the breakdown of a relationship, but it was his ex-partner who put him in contact with Tracy, and also sponsored him £ to take part in the challenge.He was also sponsored £ by Caroline Semple, of Campbeltown charity Shopper-Aide, whose idea it was to do the walk in drag.Tom explained: #I asked everyone to sponsor me £ and Caroline told me she would give me £I did it in drag. I couldn’t do it in drag every day – it would be too inconvenient to get my make up done # but I suggested doing the last day in drag and she said fair enough, she#d sponsor me £.#Tom has raised between £ and £ in total.#People have been really generous,# he said. #I hoped I would raise £ but it spiralled and people started offering me more and more money, especiallyI did it in drag.#He received help from Beckie Shields, also from Shopper-Aide, who applied his glamorous make-up ahead of Monday#s walk.He added: #Finding the motivation to get out the house can be really dficult, so having this challenge was brilliant it did me the world of good.#I think I will keep up the walking – not seven days a week but maybe Monday to Friday. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.After a long five months out of the water, swimmers from Kintyre ASC were delighted to get back to the pool as soon as restrictions were lted.Based at Aqualibrium, the club worked closely with Live Argyll to ensure that an organised, phasedwas put in place with the swimmers among the first in Scotland toto the water.Lockdown was particularly challenging for Kintyre ASC swimmers as nothing comes close to training in the same environment that they compete in but the club organised Zoom sessions with Live Argyll#s Jake Sanders and had regular online sessions as part of the Argyll and Clyde Swim Team.Swimmers stayed as active as they could in their own ways while ACST swimmers and coaches took part in a Q and A on Zoom with Scottish Olympic swimmer Hannah Miley.Club training has gradually increased and the club is almost back to where it was prior to lockdown with swimmers attending most sessions ‘pool ready’ to avoid using the changing rooms.Kintyre’s Evie Judge was again selected for Scottish Swimming’s District RegionalEvie had successfully qualied for the Scottish National Age Group Championshipsand was looking forward to swimming in Aberdeen when the pandemic hit and all events in the swimming calendar were cancelled.This year’s DRP programme was successfully held over Zoom with three sessions scheduled.Evie enjoyed this year#s experience although slightly dferent from the normal sessions usually held in Cumbernauld.She took part in group breakout sessions learning about aerobic and anaerobic speed training.In the final session she learned about the importance of ‘preparation’ and ‘visualisation’ as well as watching an excellent presentation by senior swimmer Katie Robertson followed by an informative Q and A discussion.Over recent training sessions the swimmers have been competing in this year’s Argyll and Clyde Championships virtually.Instead of swimmers travelling and meeting up at the same venue, which is not allowed under current restrictions, it was decided this year to hold the championships virtually.Clubs simply time swimmers in events at their own pool, following safe protocols, and submit results for the overall championships.Head coach Stuart McQuaker said: #What has been unbelievable is the personal best times that swimmers have been recording here, showing that as a club Kintyre AC is getting back to the competitive level that it was at before the pandemic struck.#It’s just unfortunate swimmers are unable to compete on a bigger stage at present.#Kintyre ASC top squad swimmers have also been getting timed for Scottish Swimming’s Tighinn Comhla , a National Virtual Gathering.

Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.The Courier continues to share more from the previously unpublished prisoner of war diary written by Campbeltown soldier Gunner Neil MacLean who was captured following the st Highland Division’s surrender at St Valéry-en-Caux during the Second World War.The diary, and several photographs of Neil, during and after the war, were supplied by Neil’s son Calum, who knew nothing of the diary until after his father’s death.This week continues from June :June – Had a long walk to Willinberg XXB. Raining heavy. The usual standing about for hours then into billets  men in each small room. A rotten camp.The lice have started again. Dinners here not very good but luckily we have plenty RC tins with us. , British here,  French, some Poles, Belgium, etc. Hope we are not long in this dump.th, got registered at pm and then received a complete battledress and overcoat .Moved out of Willinberg XXB on the th, searched and then about one and a half hours walk to the station. Passed some lovely houses and through a large town, Aidenberg  Very nice.Landed at station.  men in cattle truck, wanted to put us in to  men but complained so they put us in with the passengers. With our new rig out on it just seemed we were going home on leave. Lovely scenery, short run.Arrived at our place about midnight and  men here before us. Our billet is in with a lot of German soldiers and we get what they have. Nice wooden beds, double deck, pillow, two blankets etc.Dinner very good and bread ration, one loaf between three, sausage and honey etc for tea. Very happy here for my first day. Four Campbeltown boys together. Settled down here now. All kinds of work from farming to labouring. Find the bread ration not plenty when working hard all day. Can#t buy bread, tobacco or anything like that. Word of us going back to our head camp.July – st, another  men arrived today. Makes the company up to  now. July th, another  men arrived. Hear we are moving out on Tuesday,  of us.Moved out on the th. We were ordered to split into two, they wanted to separate us but managed to get together. Four Campbeltown boys. Driven out in a horse wagon about  km and arrived at Louisenberg on a farm.Billeted in to two rooms on the farm. Received a good dinner. Meals for first week # breakfast am, one slice of bread am, one slice of bread and jam dinner, soup and buttermilk pm one and a half slices of bread tea, pm, potatoes and buttermilk.Working hours – up at .am, start am. One and a half hours for dinner and work till pm. Off all day on a Sunday. A very long working week at hay and hoeing. Having finished, we started cutting the harvest. Very poor, out three fields with reaper and fourth with binder.The guard we had was always chasing us up. Th – I could not stand him any longer and we had words, furious, he took his rle down and was going to give it to me in the rear end twice. The next day we had a change of guard, better than the first one.The end of July working hard. The food just so-so, always potatoes, waiting for Red Cross Parcelto come. The farmer stands over us most of the day.August – Half another month in, working away at the harvest and taking in thrashings. On the th we received a month’s supply of RCPs and did enjoy them. A big change from always potatoes.Our guard had to go away as his we was ill. A new one came in his place and seems very nice. Receiving our mail once a week now. It seems to be better that way.The end of August and nearly all the harvest in. The food has improved this month, maybe we noticed it with us having our RCP.Received our first pay here. RCP finished, waiting for next month’s issue to come. Not much mail lately, hope next month is better. Our [illegible] storks here left the farm this month. Was off work one and a half daywith a tummy ache.Continued in next week’s Courier.

We had a number of quotes from overseas to build her but we wanted to keep the work in Scotland.’Other guests at the naming included Sir William Lithgow and his we Lady Lithgow, Argyll and Bute MP Mrs Ray Michie, Argyll and Bute District Council chairman George McMillan and district Councillor Archie McCallum.FIFTY YEARS AGOUnique legal historyMaking his first appearance as a solicitor at Campbeltown Sherf Court on Friday was Mr Patrick Stewart, son of procurator fiscal, Mr A I B Stewart.Mr Stewart is the third generation to act as a solicitor in Campbeltown. title: retired-musselburgh-journalist-george-campbell-cunningham-publishes-first-book
story: George Campbell Cunningham, , of Greenfield Park, Monktonhall, is a former convener of Tyne and Esk Writers, and features an ldquoeclectic mix of  short stories in his publication Her Holiness The Pope.He said: ldquoSome are slightly thought-provoking while others have a sting in the tail others are simply funny.Mr Cunningham said: ldquoI was idly scrolling through some computer files one day when I came across a couple of short stories I had written some time ago and forgotten about, so I set about finding how many others there were.ldquoSome were only half written, other were just outline ideas and most needed a complete re-write.ldquoSo I set about editing and in some cases just taking the theme and producing a new version.Although fictional, some of the stories are set in real historical events.Mr Cunningham, a former pupil of the Royal High School in Edinburgh, said his stories ranged ldquofrom seeing great events through the eyes of those who were there to antics in a government press office that brings central London grinding to a halt, adding: ldquoOne story records the exchange between a husband and we at a funeral tea and raises, in a humorous way, whether a flat cap is a bunnet or a hat!ldquoAt one time, there were a number of magazines on bookstalls made up of short stories and were ideal for people who were commuting. In some small way, I hope this book helps fill the gap.Mr Cunningham has always wanted to write from an early age and went on to become a trainee journalist on the Scottish .He said: ldquoI was brought up in a family that enjoyed reading books so that became my inspiration.ldquoI became a journalist thinking that might be the route to writing novels ndash but I was wrong. Thinking like a journalist does not really make creative writing easy.ldquoTo help me make the transition, I joined the Musselburgh group of Tyne and Esk Writers and that became my launch pad to creative writing.ldquoAlthough I left school with no real qualications, I discovered early in my association that Glasgow University ran a Master of Letters degree course by distanced learning and, on the basis of my CV and samples of my writing, I was admitted to the course ndash all thanks to Tyne and Esk Writers.He added: ldquoAs the world of newspapers began to shrink, I joined the Government Information Servicein Edinburgh, ending my association with the GIS as a spokesman for the Royal Air Force in Scotland.ldquoI then ventured into the world of commercial PR, eventually setting up on my own. I loved digging out offbeat articles for my clientsrsquo activities.ldquoFor me, observation is an essential skill for anyone wanting to be a creative writer ndash along, of course, with a vivid imagination.For more information and to order a signed copy, send your details to stillwriting now@gmail

He ed home on May .Daughter Gillian said: ldquoIt was an extremely worrying time for the whole family indeed. Dad is now making good progress in his recovery.ldquoSadly, all the family couldnrsquot enjoy their special day with them due to Covid restrictions but hope still to go ahead with a big family lunch next year to celebrate.The couple said the main crux of their long and happy marriage was that ldquono matter what happens in le,you work through it together and have love for each other and around you, thatrsquos all that matters.ldquoLove conquers all! they stressed.Gillian added: ldquoMum and dad are truly our king and queen of our family and we couldnrsquot be prouder of them both.

title: young-peoples-support-group-heavy-sound-raising-5-000-christmas-campaign
story: Heavy Sound, a community interest company, works with those aged  to  who are not engaged with the education system or who are in care and have been referred by Childrenrsquos Hearings Scotland.The youngsters might be struggling with the education system or live in a traumatic household with parents who cannot look after themselves or their children.Heavy Sound, launched by Jordan Butler, who himself experienced extreme hardship as a teenager, runs music and sports projects to teach skills and build confidence.A spokeswoman for Heavy Sound said: ldquoWe get referrals through social work and through education systems, the high schools.ldquoWersquove got computers, a skills lab where people can do all sorts of learning ndash arithmetic and writing -- talk about education and jobs, but we also have a huge space which wersquove turned into a gym, and we have a recording studio.A typical day with the group, which moved from its office in Tranent to Cockenzie Business Hub, might see a teenager learning the martial art Muay Thai in the gym having a one-to-one discussion with a coach on fitness, healthy eating and avoiding conflict and taking part in a music session DJing, writing lyrics and producing tracks on state-of-the-art recording equipment.Throughout the day, youngsters also have the opportunity to take part in their choice of activities, including bike maintenance, bike rides and creative arts such as expressive art spray painting.The group also operates the Community Reach  Inclusion Bus , a single-decker bus which has been turned into a mobile recording studio and music lab, and visits schools and areas of deprivation.During lockdown, when young people were unable to join the group projects, Heavy Sound delivered , weekly food parcels, made  bulk community kitchen deliveries and , shopping deliveries, and distributed , lunch bags and meals throughout East Lothian and Edinburgh.The spokeswoman said: ldquoThe total cost of funding a young personrsquos day at Heavy Sound is pound..ldquoOur hope is that, by raising pound,, we will enable another  sessions to be experienced by those who need it the most.ldquoOur work highlights the fact that having one positive and trusted relationship in a young personrsquos le can be all they need to go on and achieve what might seem like the impossible.To donate to the Heavy Sound Christmas fund, title: dunbar-man-pushed-woman-onto-hotel-bed-grabbed-neck
story: Ross Currie, of Castle Street, assaulted the woman by seizing her by the neck at the Hampton by Hilton hotel in the cityrsquos Fountainbridge.Currie uttered threats of violence before he pushed the woman onto a bed within a room at the hotel and began to restrict her breathing.He also placed a piece of clothing around her neck and restricted her breathing, all to the womanrsquos injury, at the Capital hotel on October .Currie admitted the attack on November  at Edinburgh Sherf Court and he was back in the dock for sentencing last Friday.Lawyer Phil Moore said that -year-old Currie had committed ldquoa serious offence but he has shown remorse.Sherf Adrian Cottam said: ldquoIt could have resulted in tragic consequences easily, even though Irsquom sure you didnrsquot mean that. title: tims-tales-trees-helping-hand
story: Itrsquos dark so early at this time that there is no daylight after teatime for us to enjoy our walks in a wood or by the sea, which is our tradition. Instead, we often do a night tour of the streets looking at the Christmas lights so many people have made the effort to display.Weekends have become our time to explore the woods and on Saturday the weather allowed us to venture out, after a few days of rain. We knew it would be muddy, and the trees bare of leaves, but we were on the hunt for holly and ivy to make our Christmas wreath and decorate the house.Itrsquos only when you venture into a wood in winter time that you fully appreciate the display of green that holly and ivy provides. They are naturersquos Christmas lights of colour, a gt of green in a sleeping wood that has lost most of its colour.I have written before about the mental health benefits of ldquoforest bathing, and for me regular visits to nature and walking amongst trees have always been a vital part of my mental wellbeing. And so as we ventured forth to a wood in East Lothian after days of being cooped up inside, I could feel my spirit lt.We arrived as the sun was already lowering in the winter sky. We had just two hours for our adventure and so we headed down into the wood.The sound of the Sauchet Water, which runs through the wood, reached us before we could see it. The rain of previous days had turned it into a tumbling river. I had hoped for this, as the sound of running water in naturersquos setting is so therapeutic. The kids stood by the bank, watching and listening to the river as it flowed past them, mesmerised by the sight and sound of it. I watched them as they stood together, saying nothing, but sharing the moment.After a few minutes, they came out of their trance and headed deeper into the wood to seek adventure. Our task was to find nice branches of holly and some ivy, but also to seek out the stories of the wood.And they found a story. A tree was in danger of falling because the river had eroded the bank. One side of its root system was exposed, with nothing to hold on to, so the tree was leaning towards the water, in danger of falling. But a neighbouring tree looked asit had come to the rescue. Its trunk was bending towards the tree in danger, giving it something to lean on.The kids called them the lsquoslipping treersquo and the lsquohelping treersquo. And when we looked at the roots of the two trees, we could see that they were, as my son described it, ldquoholding hands. I could see what he meant, for the roots of the lsquoslipping treersquo looked asthey were indeed holding onto the roots of the lsquohelping treersquo.Perhaps this was all their creative imagination, although there is clear scientic evidence that trees in a wood need each other and help each other in many dferent ways, especially via their underground root system. Andyou really look at trees, you will see the stories of their challenges, and of their resilience and survival in the face of them.The kids moved on in their adventure, but I paused for a moment at these two trees. There was a story here that spoke to me so directly in this most challenging of times: that we need to hold hands like this sometimes, by seeking and accepting the help of otherswe feel ourselves slipping. But also, we need to be able to recognise when someone  is quietly slipping and help them hold on.ldquoCome on, dad, we have found a perfect holly bush, the kids called out. My we Kate and I scrambled up the muddy slope to see, and sure enough they had.There is understandably a wealth of folklore and tradition about holly. Itrsquos said to be bad luck to cut the tree down but taking a small branch is OK, as long as you thank the tree.By this time, darkness was falling and the wood was feeling eerie, but in a good way. Part of exploring nature should be the enchantment of it, the mysteries it holds, and it being a bit scary at times is part of this.The bare branches of the trees silhouetted against a darkening sky was the perfect theatre to end our adventure, as the kids kept an eye out for faeries and malevolent magical creatures, which they knew would be kept at bay as long as they held onto their holly branches.We emerged from the wood into the dying light of the winterrsquos day, decorated with holly and ivy like figures from mythology ourselves.Such was our adventure last weekend. I felt so much better after the walk. Yes, it was the physical exercise and fresh air, but it was also the spiritual uplt a visit to the woods always gives, even in winter.And part of this,we choose to notice and listen, will be naturersquos stories, which can speak directly to us.

title: east-lothian-peeps-past-december-8-11-1995-1970-1920
story: A FAMOUS landmark atop North Berwick Law was in need of repair, reported the East Lothian Courier of December , .The whalersquos jawbone at the summit of North Berwick Law is to be repaired at a cost of about pound.The condition of the well-known local landmark has deteriorated over the decades and the townrsquos community councillors are keen to ensure it is saved for posterity.They approached the district council with their concerns and Macmerry-based specialists Ralph Plastics was contracted to do the job.They will restore the jawbone with fibre glass, and the protective railings around it will be repaired by Daw Engineering of Fenton Barns.Scaffolding will have to be used to carry out the work and the equipment will be taken up the hill by a tractor vehicle ndash a far cry from the mode of transport used to get the jawbone to the top in the s.lsquoWANTED,  beds for touring cyclistsrsquo was a headline in The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .The Scottish Milk Race will again be passing through Dunbar on July , .The race took Dunbar into its tour of the country two years ago and caused great excitement.The only problem is where to put all the cyclists, race officials and representatives of the Milk Marketing Board when they arrive ndash  beds are needed.Co-operation is being asked for from local people and those living within a -mile radius of the town.MEANWHILE, power cuts hit the county.Scenes reminiscent of the wartime blackout were re-created in East Lothian this week when ious parts of the County were suddenly plunged into darkness by power cuts.Ironmongers, grocers and little general dealers shops found themselves almost besieged by customers clamouring for candles, paraffin and flashlight batteries.Those in the Tranent area were the first to feel the effects.A NEW bus service was introduced in Tranent, the first of its kind. The story made headlines in The Haddingtonshire Courier on December , .The motor bus service, inaugurated on Saturday by the Scottish Motor Traction Co., between Tranent and Edinburgh, was fully taken advantage of.On Saturday and Sunday, a considerable number of people preferred to travel direct to Edinburgh rather than undertake the long walk to Prestonpans station.On some of the journeys the motors were crowded, and on thejourney, on Sunday night, the service had to be duplicated.

title: town-centre-planned-new-town-blindwells-redesigned
story: The first residents of the new town of Blindwells are expected to move in by September next year.However, developers Hargreaves have revealed that the masterplan for the town, which will see an initial population in , new homes, has been revised to create a new shopping centre to fit demand.Speaking during a virtual public consultation on the detailed plans for the town centre, Iain Slater from Hargreaves, said that while they had initially been steeredby East Lothian Council planners towards a mini retail park and supermarket at he heart of the town, times had changed.He said: ldquoRetail has changed signicantly. While it was once all about going to the supermarket for a big shop, now it is more about deliveries and just going out to buy what you want for that evening.ldquoEast Lothian Council had guided us towards a mini retail park but it is not really sustainable, which is why we have gone back to the town centre.Mr Slater said that the developers had redrawn the town centre to create smaller shops with residential properties above them.Drawings produced during the webinar showed the new town centre based around a body of water to be named The Princes Loch at the north of the site.A market square and Mercat Cross appeared in artistrsquos impressions of the new high street, while boutique shops with four-storey-high buildings lined it, with ground floor shops and flats above.Proposed on the new high street are also a health centre, gym, family pub and restaurant, and cafes.And at the loch itself, there are plans for a potential cultural centre for the Battle of Prestonpans Trust, which has been in discussions with developers to mark the historic battle on the site.Developers also confirmed that initial hopes for a railway station in Blindwells had been ruled out by Network Rail, although it might be revisited when the town expands.East Lothian Councilrsquos Local Development Plan includes the initial delivery of Blindwells with a town centre, housing and new primary school.It also has a larger area of land to the east of the town ndash which sits between Prestonpans and Tranent ndashwhich has been dubbed Greater Blindwells for future expansion.Mr Slater said that as well as a possible rail station in Greater Blindwells, there was also the possibility of a new secondary school being built but added that this was still ldquoat a very early stage in plans for the future.Current education plans for children and young people moving into Blindwells will see primary-school children bussed to classes at neighbouring Cockenzie Primary School until completion of the new primary school, now due to be delivered on site for school session  .Secondary-school pupils will travel to Preston Lodge High School in Prestonpans.Concerns about the travel plans for school pupils, impact of the new town on the existing junctions on and off the A, and environmental impact were all raised by members of the public during the virtual consultation.Asked about the demographic planned for the new town, James Fraser from EMA Architects, which produced the masterplan, said the aim was to build a community.He said: ldquoIt is about trying to create a community, so all types of people will be welcome, from first-timebuyers to families and older people looking to downsize to a smaller home.The consultation remains open online until January  for comments atwww.blindwellsconsultation

title: reopening-swimming-pool-musselburgh-sports-centre-delayed
story: It was due to have reopened on Sunday, but "an issue during commissioning" has caused a delay.The pool has been closed since October  to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed.This provides deeper or shallower depths to allow for dferent activities, like ing or childrens swimming.A spokesperson for enjoyleisure, which manages the facility, said: "The pool was closed to enable a new replacement moving floor to be installed, which is a major investment in the long-term sustainability of the swimming pool for the benefit of the community and a wide range of users."However, the work has encountered an issue during commissioning and will delay the reopening."We are working with the contractors to ensure that this is rectied as soon as possible."Whilst we are extremely disappointed in having to take this decision, the care of our customers is always our top priority and, while we know many people will be disappointed by the delay in reopening, we hope they will understand that it is for safety reasons."We are in the process of contacting everyone who has a booking that will be affected by this delay and will announce a new reopening date as soon as we can."

title: presents-left-prestonpans-bus-shelter-every-day-advent
story: Throughout this month, the anonymous kind souls behind the @PPansBus Shelter Twitter account are dropping off a gt each day for people to find and keep.Not only that but Pencaitland-based artist Lynn Fraser has painted seasonal pictures on the shelter to cheer up passers-by.Lynn told the Courier: ldquoIrsquove been following @PPansBusShelter on Twitter for a couple of years now and they just do these lovely things they leave tiny little figures sitting on little seats in the bus stop. Itrsquos just really quirky and it makes me smile.ldquoFor National Poetry Day, they put up poems on posters all round the bus shelter.ldquoBut I donrsquot know who they are!ldquoWhoever secretly runs the Twitter account leaves a little gt every day for anyone to find.ldquoI messaged them and said Irsquod like to paint Christmas scenes on the shelter, and they said go for it! So I did.A spokesperson for the Twitter account of the Northfield House bus shelter on Preston Road told the Courier: ldquoEach year the bus shelter is decorated for Christmas and, last year, small mystery packages were left in the run-up to Christmas.ldquoThis year, in conjunction with other bus stops on Twitter , Prestonpans Bus Shelter is taking part in #BusStopAdvent and small gtsare being left daily in the bus shelter.ldquoPeople who find a gt are encouraged to share on Twitter using the hashtag #BusStopAdvent.Lynn added: ldquoI love that they put out this little smile for the community. I just wanted to add to the fun.

title: disused-phone-box-musselburgh-turned-floral-planter
story: Environment group Love Musselburgh C.I.C is set to give the phone box at Eskside West a new lease of le ndash as a floral planter.It will be repainted its original red colour and all the perspex window  have been removed. BT has also taken away the phone.Baskets will be put inside and the flowers will be allowed to grow out and over the empty windows.Melanie Roccio, of Love Musselburgh, said she was inspired to go ahead with the project after seeing a phone box in Tranent that was transformed by the Blooming Belters team.She contacted the Musselburgh-based CHANGES Community Health Project to askit would lsquoadoptrsquo the phone box from BT and allow Love Musselburgh to convert it into a planter.She said: ldquoAs a community interest company, we were unfortunately not eligible to apply, andnobody adopted it, it was going to be removed.CHANGES duly obliged and lsquoadoptedrsquo the phone box.Melanie said: ldquoI askedanybody could donate their time or equipment to power wash the kiosk for us.ldquoIt had been used as a toilet for a while and needed a really good clean.ldquoDanny Nuttall, from Cowan Professional Cleaning Services, was happy to help. He came along, spending loads of time making sure it was safe to work on.ldquoMyself and my friend Steve Croasdale have spent some time sanding and prepping the phonebox and we will use paint kindly donated by Hamill Decorating Services, although wersquoll need to wait for better weather.ldquoSeveral residents of West Holmes Gardens are members of Love Musselburgh, having signed up to our Adopt a Street campaign.ldquoWith the phonebox being just around the corner from them, they generously donated pound to put towards the cost of the conversion to a planter. It was completely unexpected and very much appreciated.Melanie added: ldquoWersquove also had lots of offers of help donations of materials from local residents, businesses and organisations, and would like to thank them all.ldquoWe hope to start planting in early spring and would be grateful for any green-fingered volunteers who could help us with the ongoing care of the flowers.Since BT launched its Adopt a Kiosk scheme, more than , communities across the UK have seized the opportunity to transform local phone boxes that had little or no usage.The growth of the mobile phone industry has seen phone box usage fall dramatically. Nearly half the phone boxes in the UK have been removed, but there are still about , red phone boxes which can be adopted.The Adopt a Kiosk scheme has been successful in transforming unused payphone kiosks and preserves their heritage, particularly in rural locations. It costs pound to adopt a phone box.

title: new-community-pantry-opens-tranent-help-people-need
story: Based in the Volunteer Centre East Lothianoffice on High Street, the new pantry aims to ldquocomplement East Lothian Foodbank ndash which is also based in the town ndash by providing food and essentials to those in need.Those who use the pantry will have access both to public donations and also to surplus supermarket food from Fareshare.Both fresh and frozen items are available, alongside dried food and toiletries.Launched on Monday, November , the community-run pantry is free, open to all and no referrals are needed. It is open Monday-Friday, .am-noon.It is overseen by VCEL, as well as the Pennypit Trustrsquos Fundamental Foods team and Farsquoside Area Partnership.VCEL said that the pantry would help those in need or who were financially struggling to reduce their shopping bills and allow them to free up money for other essentials, allowing those on tight budgets to let their money stretch further ndash something it said was especially helpful in the current climate.Both the Pennypit Trust, which set up the pantry, and VCEL have seen an increase in demand for crisis food support since the coronavirus pandemic started.Carrie Richmond, from Fundamental Foods, said: ldquoIt has been a dficult time for everyone, many peoplersquos household budgets are under pressure, and Covid- has made pressures on households, especially low-income households, even greater. The pandemic has shown that local pantries are rapidly emerging in response.ldquoThis pantry will complement the work of the local foodbank and can be a useful stepping stone, helping people reduce their food costs, feed themselves or their families, and keep more money in the household to pay other bills.ldquoIt is stocked with a iety of food donated by the local community and uses surplus food from supermarkets such as Aldi and Farmfoods.ldquoIt is a positive legacy from the emergency food hub that was set up at St Martinrsquos Church Hall during lockdown.ldquoWe are extremely grateful to the community for their generous donations, especially Bisset  Steedman for a brand-new fridge freezer, East Lothian Foodbank, VCEL for providing a welcoming space for the pantry and also Farsquoside Community Kitchenfor providing fresh, homecooked meals.Maureen Allan, chief officer at VCEL, said: ldquoIt is a great privilege to work with the Pennypit Trust on this fantastic initiative.ldquoThe community pantry is open to everyone in our community and we look forward to opening our building to more initiatives like this and to the communities in East Lothian.Those at the pantry are now appealing for donations as stocks are running low, with dried and tinned food items, toiletries and utility items all welcome. Examples of food items that can be donated include tinned fruit and vegetables, lentils, cooking oils, longle milk, sugar, coffee, biscuits, jam, soup, fruit juice, tinned meals, cooking sauces, baby food and formula, fruit juice, and dog and cat food.Toiletry and cleaning products such as toilet roll, wipes, washing powder, cleaning products, hair and body care, deodorant, toothbrushes and toothpaste are also welcome.The pantry has a fridge and freezer so items such as milk, cheese, yogurts, meat products and other frozen goods can also be donated. Donations of carrier bags are also appreciated.Those wishing to make cash donations can do so the money will go towards the running of the pantry.Those with any questions or wanting to offer their support are asked to call  .

title: unusual-fox-rocks-sighting-dunbar
story: Debbie Adamson was strolling on the coastal path above the clfs at Winterfield last Thursday when she spotted the creature lying still on rocks offshore.Debbie said: ldquoIrsquom originally from Africa, so Irsquom used to game viewing, and I saw something that looked out of place on the rocks but it was quite far out and I was worried that it was a dog. I didnrsquot even think it would be a fox, to be honest.Debbie took some shots with the camera on her phone and sent them to the Coastguard, who confirmed it was a fox and said they could not attend.Debbie said: ldquoIt was on the rocks in the shallows, which would have been a great risk to the Coastguard vessel.ldquoAnother lady who was passing had a telescope, and she had a look at it and confirmed it was alive.But the fox wasnrsquot moving, and Debbie said she and the other woman watched as the tide rose and half-covered the animal.ldquoThe tide was coming in, and the fox could have moved higher up the rock but it didnrsquot, she said. ldquoIts tail started floating and the woman with the telescope wanted to leave because we were both pretty convinced it wasnrsquot going to have a happy ending.But, said Debbie, as the water reached midway up the crafty creaturersquos back, ldquoit just swam.She added: ldquoI expected it to go to one of the other rocks because there were other rocks still above water, but it didnrsquot ndash it just made a beeline for the shore.Debbie and dog Tamba watched as the plucky fox swam m to dry land.Debbie, who has lived near Dunbarrsquos Winterfield Park for seven years said: ldquoIt swam really fast. I couldnrsquot believe how quickly it could swim.ldquoI tried to see what happened when it finally got to shore but it disappeared pretty quickly.ldquoThere were a couple of people walking past and I was like, therersquos a fox on the rocks! I felt like Dr Seuss!A spokesperson for East Lothian Councilrsquos Countryside Rangers said: ldquoItrsquos possible that the fox was foraging on the shore and spotted something of interest. Alternatively, it may have been spooked by something on dry land.

title: musselburgh-baptist-churchs-hampers-food-need-christmas
story: Instead, lsquoblessing boxesrsquo containing food are being offered to people in the Musselburgh area who are struggling this festive season, and the Basics Bank, which also offers food donations, will be open until Thursday .Pastor Graham Shearer said: ldquoWe are very sad to announce that we are unable to host our usual Christmas Day meal for the community this year.ldquoWe have loved opening our doors for the last number of years but Covid- has made it impossible this time around.ldquoInstead, we are planning to give out hampers with enough food for iniduals or a family to enjoy a delicious Christmas meal at home. These hampers will include a turkey and roast ham meal with trimmings, dessert and a bottle of Shloer.The hampers will also contain some long-le and cupboard ingredients.Mr Shearer said: ldquoOur hope is that those who receive these hampers will be reminded that their community cares for them.ldquoDespite the many months of social distancing, we want to reassure people that they are not on their own ndash they matter, they are loved.ldquoAs a community, we have lost so much this year. So we want this Christmas to be about bringing a hope and a peace that not even Covid can take away.Last yearrsquos Christmas Day lunch at the church ndash funded by donations ndash attracted about  people, who joined together to enjoy a free three-course dinner cooked and served up by a team of  volunteers.The invitation was extended to those who would be on their own during the festive season, residents in financial crisis, the bereaved or families which had split up and couldnrsquot afford a Christmas meal.Anyone who would like to receive a hamper or to request one for a neighbour or family member should contact the church on   or at info@mus selburghbaptist.orgThe hampers will be available to collect from the church at  New Street on December  or .The Basics Bank at the church is usually for people who are officially referred but no one in need is turned away empty-handed.Mr Shearer said: ldquoThroughout the pandemic, we have still been able to keep going with our Basics Bank on Thursday mornings from am to noon.ldquoSo we are increasingly aware that many remain isolated and in need around the Musselburgh and East Lothian area.The church is still holding its candlelit Christmas services in keeping with Government guidelines on numbers and social distancing.Four separate services take place on December  and . They will offer a time to sit and reflect over the year, to meditate on the meaning of Christmas and listen to carols sung by soloists.There are four times to choose from and tickets are free.Reserve seats at musselburghbaptist.org christmas-

title: margiotta-hopes-transform-gullane-gym-convenience-store
story: Margiotta wants to revamp Gullane Gym and create a second county store, after opening in Aberlady earlier this year.Franco Margiotta, managing director of the Edinburgh-based chain, confirmed that proposals to change the use of the building, on Gullanersquos Hall Crescent, were now with East Lothian Council.He recognised that there were already stores in the village but added: ldquoHopefully, there will be enough room for all of us with the new housing that is being built.ldquoWe would be building on the success we have had in Aberlady, which just encouraged us to move along the road, as it were.Currently, the business has seven stores across Edinburgh and Midlothian, as well as the Aberlady branch.Mr Margiotta was hopeful more than a dozen jobs could be created at the Gullane store,approved.He stressed that the decision lay in the hands of the local authority but,approval was given, they could be on site in the spring.Mr Margiotta told the Courier: ldquoAberlady has been successful for us and we seem to have hit a spot with the local people and received a very, very warm welcome.It has just encouraged us to look further afield.ldquoBoth Gullane and Aberlady I am so familiar with just by visiting, playing golf, visiting the beach and walking to North Berwick.ldquoI have just a fondness for these places.The building has been on the market for more than three years, with the owner previously keen for it to be turned into flats.That would have led to the existing building being demolished and four new properties built.However, a number of residents were disappointed in these proposals, with the villagersquos bowling club among those calling for a rethink.Twice, plans came forward to East Lothian Council for four flats there.A first set of proposals was withdrawn by the applicant, with the second turned down by the local authority after  objections were lodged against the scheme.Councillor Jeremy Findlay, who lives in the village, is a member of the local authorityrsquos planning committee, which could ultimately decide the fate of the proposals.He was restricted in what he could say on the plans but added: ldquoThere was a lot of opposition against the proposals for flats.ldquoAny alternative commercial use and employment opportunities would be welcomed by the community.ldquoIt has been discussed by the community council to title: planning-permission-required-tool-shed-bolton-muir-wood
story: The forestry shed was installed in Bolton Muir Wood, an ancient woodland which lies just over a mile to the west of Gford.However, it was only after it had been erected that applicant Consequent Ltd, a Dunbar-based management consultancy, asked East Lothian Council plannersit needed planning approval.In a ruling issued by planners this week, they have raised an objection to the shed, ordering the firm to apply for retrospective planning permission.They also told the company that future plans to create a gravel path to the shed would also need planning permission.Planning officers said the shed was on a woodland parcel known as Tenter Wood, within the larger Bolton Muir Wood.In a report by officers, it was stated: ldquoThe high mature trees within this part of the woodland positively contribute to the characterand appearance of the landscape setting in which the ancient woodland is derived from.Officers ruled that the shed and proposed path would have a visual impact on the ancient woodland and said no evidence had been brought forward to show that the work would not impact on the bioersity of the site or surrounding trees.And they questioned whether trees had already been removed to clear space for the shed.Their report called on the applicant to produce a woodland management plan to go along with a planning application for the shed and any proposed path.Keith Dingwall, planning manager, told the applicant: ldquoGiven the councilrsquos reasons for the decision that planning permission is requiredhellip I strongly suggest that you discuss your proposal with the planning authority prior to the submission of a forthcoming planning application.

title: bird-flu-scotland-spot-avian-influenza-safety-measures-ramped
story: The Chief Veterinary Officers of Scotland, England and Wales agreed on the new measures, which came into force today, which will protect wild birds and poultry following cases of the ldquohighly infectious Avian influenza illness in both populations.From today, it will be a legal requirement for all bird keepers to keep their flocks indoors and to follow biosecurity measures to limit the spread and eradicate the disease.Why are we talking about it now It comes as the Scottish Government announced an examination into the deaths of three swans in Clackmannanshire over disease fears.And on Friday, avian flu was confirmed in rearing turkeys at a premises near Attleborough in Norfolk, marking eight cases in captive birds in England.Cases of the disease have also been detected in wild birds.Public Health England has said the risk to the public from the virus was ldquovery low, and food standards agencies also said it does not impact the consumption of poultry products.Last month, restrictions were declared to prevent the spread of the virus as Scotland, England and Wales were made an Avian Influenza Prevention Zone .This means that poultry and captive bird keepers must take additional steps such as disinfecting equipment, vehicles and clothing, changing clothing and footwear before entering enclosures and limiting access to non-essential people.Housing measures are in force as of today -  Dec. You must house your birds to protect them from #AvianInfluenza. Birds like #Ducks  #Geese that cannot be easily housed must be kept in netted enclosed areas. See Scotlandrsquos declaration https:t.co XysTYvGyQ @RuralMattersSG pic cePuUsgZHow to spot bird flu Avian influenza viruses can be classied according to their ability to cause severe disease as either highly pathogenic or low pathogenic.Low pathogenic bird flu is often dficult to detect, with very few clinical signs.According to the Scottish Government, an infected flock might show signs of respiratory distress, diarrhoea, or a drop in egg production.Highly pathogenic avian influenza will often form symptoms more suddenly, with affected birds developing swollen heads, a blue colouration of the comb and wattles, respiratory distress, diarrhoea, and a signicant drop in egg production.The Scottish Government guidance saysyou are suspicious your flock has any form of avian influenza you must contact your local animal health office immediately.What to doyou find a dead or sick wild birdAccording to Scottish Government guidance, wild birds can carry several diseases that are infectious to people, so do not touch or pick up any dead or visibly sick birds that you find.If you find a single dead bird of prey, gull or wildfowl species , or find five or more birds of any other species in the same location and at the same time, you should report these incidents to Defrarsquos national telephone helpline .How is bird flu spread The disease spreads from bird to bird by direct contact or through contaminated body fluids and faeces. It can also be spread by contaminated feed and water or by dirty vehicles, clothing and footwear.The avian influenza virus changes frequently, creating new strains, and there is a constant risk that one of the new strains may spread easily among people. But there is no evidence that any recent strain of avian influenza has been able to spread directly between people.Avian influenza is an airborne disease. It can also be spread by wild birds and rodents whose movements change in response to flooding.How can I find out more Full details are available on the Scottish Government website here.

title: we-lost-dad-cant-mum-yet-p-k-thinks-can-drive-269-miles-babysitter-glasgow-reacts-dominic-cummings
